issues.title: IMS Bearing Failure (997.1 Only)
issues.symptoms: Metallic debris in oil, grinding noise, catastrophic engine failure, oil pressure light
issues.description: The early 997.1 (2005-2008) with the M97 engine carries over the IMS bearing concern from the 996. However, only the base Carrera and Carrera S are affected - the Turbo and GT3 use different engines. The 997.2 (2009+) uses the 9A1 engine with a completely different design and has NO IMS bearing.
fixes: 997.1: Proactive IMS bearing replacement with upgraded bearing
LN Engineering ceramic hybrid bearing upgrade
Regular oil analysis to detect early wear
997.2: No IMS bearing - this is not a concern
Always verify engine type when purchasing a 997

issues.title: Bore Scoring (997.1 M97 Engine)
issues.symptoms: Ticking/knocking noise, smoke on cold start, oil consumption, low compression
issues.description: The M97 engine in the 997.1 can develop bore scoring similar to the M96 in the 996. Cylinder 6 is most commonly affected. The scoring damages cylinder walls, causing oil to bypass the piston rings. The 997.2 with the 9A1 engine does not have this problem.
fixes: Borescope inspection (pre-purchase inspection must include this)
Minor scoring: monitor, use quality oil, don't overheat
Moderate scoring: cylinder sleeving repair
Severe scoring: engine rebuild or replacement
Prevention: proper warm-up, quality oil, avoid short trips

repairCosts.notes: 997.1 M97 engine. Less common than 996 but still occurs.

issues.title: PDK Transmission Issues (997.2)
issues.symptoms: Jerky low-speed shifts, shuddering during engagement, warning lights, harsh 1-2 shift
issues.description: The PDK (Porsche Doppelkupplung) dual-clutch transmission in the 997.2 can develop issues, particularly with the clutch packs and mechatronic unit. Some owners report jerky behavior at low speeds, especially when cold. The transmission is generally reliable but can be expensive to repair.
fixes: Ensure latest software updates are installed
PDK fluid change (not technically required but beneficial)
Clutch adaptation reset via Porsche diagnostic tool
For severe issues: clutch pack replacement (expensive)
Mechatronic unit repair or replacement if electrical issues

repairCosts.notes: Fluid service DIY possible. Major repairs shop only.

issues.title: PASM Suspension Failures
issues.symptoms: PASM warning light, harsh ride, suspension not adjusting, clunking noises, uneven ride height
issues.description: PASM (Porsche Active Suspension Management) uses electronically adjustable dampers. The dampers can fail (usually leaking), and the PASM control module can have electrical issues. Failed dampers result in a rough ride and warning lights.
fixes: Diagnose with PIWIS/Durametric to identify failed damper
Replace failed PASM damper (OEM or remanufactured)
Convert to quality coilovers if multiple failures
Check wiring and connectors before replacing dampers
PASM control module can be rebuilt if electrical issue

issues.title: Coolant Pipe and Water Pump Failures
issues.symptoms: Coolant loss, overheating, coolant smell, puddles under car, temperature warning
issues.description: Both 997.1 and 997.2 can suffer from coolant system issues. The plastic coolant pipes, water pump, and expansion tank all degrade with age and heat. While the 997.2 improved some areas, it's still recommended to replace plastic coolant pipes with aluminum as preventive maintenance.
fixes: Replace plastic coolant pipes with aluminum upgrade kit
Replace water pump (consider with major service)
Replace expansion tank if original
Replace thermostat if over 60k miles
Flush and refill coolant every 4 years

issues.title: Direct Fuel Injection Carbon Buildup (997.2)
issues.symptoms: Rough idle, misfires, reduced power, poor fuel economy, check engine light
issues.description: The 997.2's 9A1 engine uses direct fuel injection (DFI), which doesn't wash the intake valves with fuel like port injection does. Over time, carbon deposits build up on the intake valves, causing running issues. This requires periodic cleaning, typically every 50,000-80,000 miles.
fixes: Walnut shell blasting to clean intake valves
Chemical cleaning (less effective but less invasive)
Preventive: occasional Italian tune-ups (spirited driving)
Use quality fuel with good detergent additives
Some owners add catch can to reduce oil vapor deposits

issues.title: Rear Main Seal Leak (997.1)
issues.symptoms: Oil drips from transmission bell housing, burning oil smell, oil on clutch, clutch slippage
issues.description: The 997.1 with the M97 engine can develop rear main seal leaks similar to the 996. Oil leaks onto the clutch in manual transmission cars, causing slipping. The 997.2 with the 9A1 engine has a different seal design with fewer reported issues.
fixes: Replace rear main seal (requires engine/trans separation)
Combine with IMS bearing replacement to save labor (997.1)
Replace clutch if contaminated with oil
Use updated seal design for longer life

repairCosts.notes: 997.1 only. Same M97 engine RMS issues.

guides.title: Complete Suspension Refresh
guides.description: Full front and rear suspension rebuild for the 997's MacPherson strut front and multi-link rear suspension, restoring the legendary 911 handling.
steps: Raise vehicle on jack stands at all four corners.
Remove wheels and photograph suspension.
Soak all bolts with penetrating oil.
Front: Remove sway bar links, tie rod ends, control arm bolts.
Separate ball joint from knuckle.
For struts: mark camber, remove upper mount nuts and pinch bolt (65 ft-lbs).
Replace strut mount/bearing using spring compressor.
Install new front components - control arm to frame 89 ft-lbs.
Rear: The 997's rear is critical for handling.
Support trailing arm, remove control arms (81 ft-lbs inner).
Replace thrust arms - affect toe settings.
CRITICAL: Check rear spring perches for cracks.
Install wheels and lower vehicle.
Professional alignment mandatory.
tips: The 997 is rear-engine biased - suspension issues amplified.
997.1 and 997.2 use similar suspension despite different engines.
Cracked spring perches are a known safety issue.
PASM dampers fail over time - consider replacement if leaking.
warnings: CRITICAL: Inspect rear spring perches for cracks.
Incorrect alignment causes rear instability at speed.

guides.title: Rust Prevention and Inspection
guides.description: Comprehensive rust inspection guide for the 997, which is galvanized but requires attention to water intrusion areas and drain systems.
steps: The 997 is fully galvanized - most issues are water-related.
Clean undercarriage before inspection.
Check front trunk for water - DME and fuse box located here.
Clear front trunk drain tubes.
Inspect battery box for acid corrosion.
Check headlights for moisture (bi-xenon prone to seal failure).
Examine rocker panels and door bottoms.
Check wheel wells and suspension mounts.
Surface rust: wire brush, convert, prime, topcoat.
Reseal headlights if moisture present.
Apply cavity wax to hollow sections.
Clear all drain tubes with compressed air.
tips: 997s rarely have structural rust due to galvanization.
Most corrosion from water intrusion and battery acid.
Headlight seal failure extremely common.
Annual Fluid Film prevents most issues.
warnings: Water in frunk destroys expensive electronics.

guides.title: Electrical System Service
guides.description: Complete electrical service for the 997 covering ignition, sensors, headlight resealing, and common electrical issues.
steps: Begin with diagnostic scan for fault codes.
Check front trunk for water intrusion.
For headlight reseal: remove assembly (3 bolts).
Heat headlight at 200°F for 15-20 min to soften sealant.
Separate lens, clean old butyl, apply new sealant.
For coils: open engine lid, disconnect and remove.
Inspect spark plug wells for oil.
For PASM: diagnose which damper failed, replace.
For window regulator: remove door panel, support glass, swap.
Clean all ground points.
Clear codes and verify repairs.
tips: 997 headlight condensation extremely common.
997.1 vs 997.2 have different filter locations.
VarioCam solenoid issues cause rough running - use OEM.
PASM failures trigger warning light.
warnings: Never use carburetor cleaner on MAF.
Always disconnect battery before electrical work.

guides.title: Interior Restoration
guides.description: Complete interior refresh for the 997 covering leather care, common wear items, and PCM system maintenance.
steps: Document condition with photos.
Clean leather thoroughly with dedicated cleaner.
Fill cracks with leather filler, sand smooth, apply dye.
Condition all leather surfaces.
Assess steering wheel - rewrap if worn.
Replace worn boots and knobs.
Replace cabin air filter - in frunk under carpet.
Clean HVAC vents with brushes.
Address seat bolster wear with dye or foam replacement.
Replace door seals if wind noise present.
Apply UV protectant to exposed surfaces.
tips: Sport seats wear faster on driver bolster.
Steering wheel often wears before seats.
997 leather responds well to conditioning.
HVAC clicking indicates blend actuator failure.
warnings: Steering wheel has airbag - disconnect battery.
Be careful with aged trim clips.

diyGuides.title: Oil Change
diyGuides.description: Flat-6 oil and filter change procedure for both 997.1 and 997.2.
tools: Oil filter wrench (997.1) or 76mm cap wrench (997.2)
Ramps or jack and jack stands
steps: Warm the engine for 2-3 minutes - warm oil drains more completely.
Drive onto ramps or safely raise and support the vehicle.
Locate the oil drain plug on the bottom of the engine - 19mm socket.
Position drain pan and remove drain plug - oil capacity is approximately 9 quarts.
997.1: Remove spin-on oil filter using filter wrench (located on lower right of engine).
997.2: Remove cartridge filter cap (76mm) and replace filter element.
Allow oil to drain completely (10-15 minutes for thorough drain).
Install new drain plug washer and reinstall plug - torque to 37 ft-lbs (50 Nm).
997.1: Lubricate new filter gasket with oil and install - hand tight plus 3/4 turn.
997.2: Install new filter element and o-ring, torque cap to 19 ft-lbs (26 Nm).
Lower vehicle and add approximately 8.5 quarts of 0W-40 full synthetic.
Start engine and check for leaks around drain plug and filter.
Check oil level on the dashboard - add oil as needed to reach proper level.
Reset oil service interval in instrument cluster.
tips: CRITICAL for 997.1: Cut open and inspect oil filter for metal debris - this is an early IMS bearing warning sign.
997.2 has no IMS bearing concern - different engine design (9A1).
Use quality 0W-40 oil meeting Porsche A40 spec (Mobil 1, Motul, etc.).
Consider oil analysis for 997.1 cars - helps monitor IMS bearing health.
Don't overfill - these engines are sensitive to overfilling.

diyGuides.title: Brake Pad Replacement
diyGuides.description: Front and rear brake pad replacement on 997 with optional sensor replacement.
diyGuides.interval: Every 20,000-40,000 miles depending on driving style
tools: 7mm hex/Allen socket for caliper guide pins
Brake piston retractor tool (rear uses screw-in type)
steps: Loosen wheel bolts before raising vehicle.
Raise and safely support vehicle on jack stands.
Remove wheel bolts and wheel.
Disconnect brake pad wear sensor connector if equipped.
Remove caliper guide pin bolts (7mm hex) - do not remove caliper bracket.
Swing caliper up and support it - do not let it hang by the brake hose.
Remove old brake pads and anti-rattle clips.
Clean caliper bracket and slide pins with brake cleaner and wire brush.
Inspect rotors for wear, scoring, or minimum thickness.
Front: Use brake piston tool to push piston back into caliper.
Rear: Use screw-in type retractor - piston must be rotated clockwise while pushing.
Install new anti-rattle clips and apply thin film of brake lubricant to pad backing.
Install new brake pads with wear sensor on inner pad (if equipped).
Reinstall caliper and torque guide pins to 25 ft-lbs.
Connect wear sensor and reinstall wheel - torque bolts to 118 ft-lbs (160 Nm).
Pump brake pedal several times before driving to seat pads.
tips: Replace pads in axle pairs - never replace just one side.
Wear sensors are one-time use - replace if triggered or during pad change.
Bed in new pads properly: 10 moderate stops from 40 mph, then cool down.
PCCB (ceramic brake) cars have different procedure - do not attempt without proper training.
Open brake fluid reservoir cap before compressing pistons to prevent overflow.

diyGuides.title: Spark Plug Replacement
diyGuides.description: Replace spark plugs on the M97 (997.1) or 9A1 (997.2) flat-six engine.
tools: 5/8" (16mm) spark plug socket with rubber insert
steps: Allow engine to cool completely - spark plugs in aluminum heads must be replaced cold.
Remove engine cover (if equipped) for better access.
Disconnect electrical connector from each ignition coil.
Remove coil pack mounting bolt (10mm) from each coil.
Carefully pull each coil straight up and out of the spark plug well.
Use compressed air to blow debris out of spark plug wells before removal.
Remove each spark plug using 5/8" deep socket with extension.
Inspect removed plugs for wear pattern and electrode condition.
Apply thin coat of anti-seize to new plug threads (avoid getting on electrode).
Hand-thread new plugs to avoid cross-threading in aluminum heads.
Torque spark plugs to 22 ft-lbs (30 Nm) - do not overtighten.
Apply dielectric grease inside coil boots to prevent sticking.
Reinstall coil packs and torque mounting bolts to 7.5 ft-lbs (10 Nm).
Reconnect coil electrical connectors until they click.
tips: Use NGK or Bosch plugs - these engines are sensitive to plug brand and heat range.
997.1 uses different plugs than 997.2 - verify correct part number.
Never install plugs in a hot engine - risk of stripping aluminum threads.
Gap is preset from factory - do not adjust unless specified.
If a plug feels difficult to remove, apply penetrating oil and try again rather than forcing.

diyGuides.title: Serpentine Belt Replacement
diyGuides.description: Replace the accessory drive belt on the 997 flat-six engine.
tools: Serpentine belt tool or 3/8" breaker bar
Belt routing diagram (photograph existing before removal)
steps: Open the rear deck lid and locate the accessory belt (visible from rear of engine compartment).
Take a photo or draw the belt routing before removal.
Locate the spring-loaded belt tensioner pulley.
Insert 3/8" breaker bar or serpentine belt tool into tensioner square hole.
Rotate tensioner clockwise to release belt tension.
While holding tensioner, slip belt off one of the pulleys.
Slowly release tensioner and remove belt completely.
Inspect tensioner and idler pulleys for wear, noise, or play.
Compare new belt to old belt to verify correct length and rib count.
Route new belt around all pulleys except tensioner, following diagram.
Rotate tensioner and slip belt over final pulley.
Release tensioner slowly and verify belt is properly seated in all grooves.
Start engine briefly and verify belt tracks correctly with no squealing.
tips: Replace tensioner and idler pulley if over 80,000 miles or showing wear.
A squealing belt on startup usually indicates worn belt or tensioner.
Always verify belt is fully seated in all pulley grooves before starting.
Keep hands clear when releasing tensioner - significant spring pressure.
Some owners do this from underneath the car - personal preference.

buyersGuide.overview: The Porsche 997 (2005-2012) is considered by many to be the best all-around 911 generation - modern enough to be reliable daily drivers yet traditional enough to maintain classic 911 character. The return to round headlights addressed 996 styling criticisms, while the drivetrain evolved from the M96/M97 to the improved 9A1 engine in 2009. The 997 offers exceptional performance (325-620 hp depending on variant) with better reliability than the 996. GT3, GT3 RS, and GT2 RS variants are among the most collectible modern Porsches.

variants.name: Carrera / Carrera S (997.1)
variants.description: First generation with 3.6L (325 hp) or 3.8L (355 hp). Still has IMS bearing (improved design). The S is the sweet spot.

variants.name: Carrera / Carrera S (997.2)
variants.description: Second generation with DFI (direct fuel injection) 3.6L (345 hp) or 3.8L (385 hp). No IMS bearing. PDK available.

variants.name: Carrera 4 / Carrera 4S
variants.description: All-wheel drive variants. Widebody styling on 4S. More stable in all conditions.

variants.name: GT3 / GT3 RS
variants.description: Track-focused with Mezger engine (435-450 hp). No IMS concerns. The RS adds aero and weight savings. Highly collectible.

variants.name: Turbo / Turbo S
variants.description: Twin-turbo with 480-530 hp. All-wheel drive standard. Mezger engine on 997.1, DFI on 997.2.

variants.name: GT2 / GT2 RS
variants.description: Rear-wheel drive Turbo with 530-620 hp. The most extreme 997. GT2 RS is legendary.

items.detail: 997.1 still has IMS bearing but improved design. Failure is less common but still possible. Check if retrofitted.
M97 engine can develop cylinder bore scoring. Check for knocking, smoke, or oil consumption.
Early 997.1 engines can suffer from crankcase cooling duct failure.
DFI engines can develop intake valve carbon buildup. May need walnut blasting at high mileage.
DFI injectors can fail causing rough running. Usually diagnosed with scan tool.
Some oil consumption is normal. Monitor level between services.
Test all gears. G97 6-speed is robust and well-regarded.
Check for smooth operation and proper clutch wear. PDK requires fluid service.
Manual car clutch engagement should be smooth. Dual-mass flywheel is expensive.
If equipped, test in all modes. Shocks can develop leaks.
Check for clunking and worn bushings. Common wear item.
Ceramic brakes are expensive to replace. Check rotor condition.
Check touchscreen function and navigation. Older units may need updates.
Test full operation including automatic wind blocker if equipped.
Driver side bolster wear is common on sport seats.

project.description: 997.1 cars with known engine issues. Salvage or high-mileage with concerns.

driver.description: Good 997.1 Carrera S or entry 997.2 examples. Excellent daily drivers.

excellent.description: Well-maintained 997.2 Carrera S/4S, clean Turbos, or lower mileage GT3.

redFlags: 997.1 with unknown IMS status or bore scoring symptoms
Check engine light with multiple codes
PCCB brakes with visible damage or wear
PDK with shudder or rough engagement
GT3/RS with track damage or unknown racing history
whatToLookFor: Carrera S or 4S for best all-around package
Manual transmission (purist choice) or PDK (faster, easier)
GT3 for track use (Mezger engine, no IMS)
Lower mileage with consistent service history
expertTips: The 997.2 (2009+) is the safest buy with no IMS bearing concerns
997.1 Turbo and GT3 use Mezger engine with excellent reliability
PDK is faster but manual is more engaging - choose based on preference
The 997 Carrera S is one of the best all-around sports cars ever made
GT3 and GT3 RS values have appreciated significantly
Avoid PCCB brakes if possible - replacement costs are extreme
Budget for proper PPI by a Porsche specialist before purchase
Join Rennlist.com for excellent owner community and resources
The 997 can be a reliable daily driver with proper maintenance
Factory sport seats and Sport Chrono add resale value
